item.title: Mecha Break Demo Player Count Reaches 300k in First Day
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/mecha-break-demo-player-count-300k

The newly-released demo for a little third-person mech shooter called Mecha Break is hitting some serious Steam player numbers, with hundreds of thousands of players flocking to check out the demo since it launched yesterday.

According to SteamDB's numbers, the Mecha Break demo reached an all-time peak of 317,522 players yesterday. To put things into perspective, that's higher than the all-time Steam player counts of games like Destiny 2, Halo Infinite, and Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2, and we know how successful the latter is.

That achievement seems even more impressive when we consider that we're comparing a demo to numbers achieved by fully-released games. Sure, these aren't quite Monster Hunter Wilds numbers, but that's a franchise with some name recognition.

Although Mecha Break is getting some big player numbers for its demo, feedback from those players hasn't been entirely positive. In fact, the demo (which has its own review numbers thanks to changes made by Valve in July) has a Mostly Negative rating across almost 4,800 reviews at time of writing.

Those who've left negative reviews point to the game's kernel-level anti-cheat, which is never a popular inclusion, as well as its monetization model and its lengthy, unskippable tutorial sequence.

Of course, there are many positive reviews as well, and even negative reviews frequently mention Mecha Break's gameplay as a positive point. Some players are also urging others to show leniency given that the demo doesn't necessarily represent the finished product.

If you're not familiar with Mecha Break, it's a multiplayer third-person shooter with - you guessed it - an emphasis on mech combat.

The game offers three distinct modes: a 3v3 deathmatch mode, a 6v6 hero shooter-style mode, and a PvPvE extraction shooter. Needless to say, that's a pretty ambitious mix. It also boasts the involvement of some pretty heavy hitters in the mech world, including Metal Gear's Takayuki Yanase and Gundam's Junya Ishigaki.

If you'd like to check out the Mecha Break demo, you can do so right now via Steam.

item.title: The Talos Principle: Reawakened Release Date Revealed for April
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/talos-principle-reawakened-release-date

Devolver Digital and Croteam have announced the release date for The Talos Principle: Reawakened, the remastered version of the two studios' philosophical 2014 puzzler.

As noted by Gematsu, The Talos Principle: Reawakened officially launches across PC and current-gen consoles (sorry, Switch owners) on April 10th. What's more, you can check a demo of the game out right now as part of the always-excellent Steam Next Fest.

Announced back in December, The Talos Principle: Reawakened is a remastered version of the 2014 original, although when it was first announced, Devolver and Croteam promised it would be "more than a remaster", serving instead as the "definitive edition" of the game.

Major changes compared to the original The Talos Principle include a full visual overhaul courtesy of a switch to Unreal Engine 5. You can expect new lighting, new visual effects, and new design elements as well.

Devolver and Croteam are also promising "modernized quality-of-life updates that maintain the vision of the original classic", although the two studios don't go into detail regarding what those changes are.

Of course, The Talos Principle: Reawakened also includes the DLC expansion Road to Gehenna, which was released in 2015. As well as that, it'll pack in a brand new chapter titled "In the Beginning", which will explore "the origins of the Simulation", according to the devs.

If you want to get a sense of some of the visual improvements made in Reawakened (although the original Talos Principle was certainly no slouch in this area), you can check out the original announcement trailer here.

In case you're not familiar with The Talos Principle, it's a puzzle game by Serious Sam developer Croteam, and it eschews the frantic action of that franchise for a more thoughtful, contemplative approach.

I don't want to spoil the game's mysteries, but suffice it to say that if you're in the mood to debate philosophy with computers and solve some brain-teasers along the way, then this is very much the game for you.

The Talos Principle: Reawakened launches on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S on April 10th. You can check out the Steam Next Fest demo of the game on PC right now.
